sentences.sentence: By Jairo Yunis and Keyli LoeppkyAccording to a recent report(https://www.cfib-fcei.ca/hubfs/research/reports/2023/2023-10-crime-safety-western-canada-en.pdf) from the Canadian Federation of Independent Business, small businesses(https://financialpost.com/category/entrepreneur/small-business/), the heart and soul of many of our neighbourhoods, are saying more work needs to be done to address crime and increase community safety.This feeling is particularly strong in Western Canada, where 41 per cent of small businesses consider crime and safety a big challenge, compared to only a quarter in the rest of the country.

This concern is wholly warranted, as nearly half of Western Canadian small businesses have been either directly or indirectly impacted by safety issues, with another third reporting themselves as 'on edge' about them.Crime and safety are not just a city problem.
Rural communities are also grappling with rising crime rates, which are exacerbated by inadequate services and infrastructure, limited police resources and challenging geography.

The disparity between urban and rural crime rates has widened in recent years, with the prairie provinces suffering(https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/en/pub/85-002-x/2023001/article/00002-eng.pdf?st=lxg2fJZ7) the highest rural crime levels.Small businesses experience crime and community safety challenges in various forms - vandalism, theft, human waste, loitering, and public intoxication.
Small businesses in Western Canada face these issues daily, but their prevalence varies by province.
While B.C.
small businesses reported their top issues as waste and litter (i.e., drug paraphernalia, human waste, etc.
), Alberta and Saskatchewan experienced theft/shoplifting the most, and Manitoba cited vandalism and breaking and entering as their number one issue.One owner of a small B.C.
business reports its employees are frequently harassed during business hours.
They also say the unsafe environment adversely impacts shoppers' willingness to visit shops on the main street because they perceive the area as high-risk.

It's truly disheartening to hear about the struggles this business and its employees are facing, and the effects on both their livelihoods and their community's well-being.In response to these challenges, owners of small business are doing what they do best: adjusting and investing, not just in private security measures but also in their communities' well-being.
They are providing safety training for their employees and finding ways to keep their doors open, serving the people they care about.

Small businesses have always been resilient and are committed to fostering safe workplaces, but many owners have spent their life savings opening and running the businesses of their dreams and can't afford, all on their own, to shoulder the burdens and stresses from dealing with the impacts of crime.The implications of crime and community safety issues are more than financial.
They disrupt the safe and welcoming environment businesses want to provide employees and customers alike.

In Western Canada, 78 per cent of small businesses indicate they are concerned about their employees' and customers' personal safety - which is to say nothing about the heartache of seeing one's life work chronically vandalized or otherwise endangered.Crime and safety issues aren't always easy to address.
Most owners of small businesses demonstrate a high level of social responsibility regarding the challenges that give rise to them.
But they aren't first responders or social workers.

The social circumstances that are forcing many to train themselves in trauma-informed care and administering Naloxone are not acceptable.Canada may not be broken but Ottawa is definitely broke(https://financialpost.com/opinion/canada-not-broken-but-ottawa-is-broke)Don't raise taxes on vape products.

They help people quit smoking(https://financialpost.com/opinion/dont-raise-taxes-vape-products-help-people-quit-smoking)Liberals' EV targets out of sync with global metal supply(https://financialpost.com/opinion/liberals-unrealistic-ev-targets-global-metal-supply)Small businesses serving on the front lines of what's happening in our neighbourhoods should have a say in how communities respond.

A good first step would be to simply face up to the fact that we need safer communities where businesses can thrive, employees can work without fear and customers can enjoy secure commercial areas once more.Jairo Yunis is economist for western Canada at the Canadian Federation of Independent Business, where Keyli Loeppky is director of interprovincial affairs.Bookmark our website and support our journalism: Don't miss the business news you need to know - add financialpost.com(https://financialpost.com/ ) to your bookmarks and sign up for our newsletters here(https://financialpost.com/newsletters/ ).
@COPYRIGHT=Â© 2023 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly uncertain about this document. The writing style and content are not particularly AI-like.
